description: A traditional Ugandan delicacy of beef hooves slow-boiled for many hours until the tough skin, tendons, and cartilage become incredibly soft, gelatinous, and tender. Served with a spicy, tangy dipping sauce.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Mlokony is a beloved street food and social snack, especially in the northern regions. It is often enjoyed in the evening, shared among friends, and paired with a cold beer or local waragi. The dish is a testament to the 'no-waste' philosophy, transforming a tough cut into a flavorful and texturally unique experience.

ingredients.name: Beef Hooves (Cleaned)
ingredients.notes: Thoroughly scrubbed and split lengthwise by the butcher

ingredients.name: Water
ingredients.notes: For boiling, more may be needed

steps.instruction: Thoroughly scrub the beef hooves under running water with a brush to remove any dirt or debris. Ensure they are split in half lengthwise.
Place the cleaned hooves in the very large pot. Add the roughly chopped onion, crushed garlic cloves, sliced ginger, and salt.
Pour enough water into the pot to completely submerge the hooves.
Bring the pot to a rolling boil over high heat. Once boiling, reduce the heat to the lowest possible setting, cover the pot, and let it simmer very gently for 6-8 hours.

cooking_indicators.visual: The water will become a rich, cloudy broth. The hooves will darken.
cooking_indicators.texture: The meat, skin, and cartilage should be extremely tender and easily separate from the bone. A fork should pierce it with no resistance.

steps.instruction: Check the pot every hour or so, adding more boiling water if necessary to keep the hooves submerged.

Once the hooves are completely tender, carefully remove them from the pot and place them on a large serving platter. They will be very soft and gelatinous. Reserve the nutrient-rich broth for drinking as a soup if desired.
Serve the Mlokony hot or at room temperature.

serving_suggestions: Serve the Mlokony on a large shared platter. Provide a spicy dipping sauce (see below) and plenty of napkins. It is traditionally eaten with the hands, sucking the tender meat and gelatin from the bones.

accompaniments.name: Kachumbari
accompaniments.description: A fresh salad of chopped tomatoes, onions, and cilantro.

accompaniments.name: Spicy Dipping Sauce
accompaniments.description: A mix of lime/lemon juice, finely chopped chili peppers (like scotch bonnet), and a pinch of salt.
